questions.content: The price of milk today is only _____ of its price in 1890 (adjusting for inflation).

choices: None of the above. Milk prices are the same.

questions.content: When Americans were surveyed about why milk can be produced using only 20% of the animal feed needed in 1945, more people answered “drugs and steroids” than “genetics and breeding”.
What was Alexis St. Martin’s contribution to the science of nutrition?

choices: By experimenting on mice, he discovered how an organism digests food
Allowing other people to place food into, and then retrieve food from, his stomach
Recognizing that the stomach of a mouse can still digest food hours after its death
Experimenting with feeding cattle feed to people, and human food to cattle (though without the humans’ awareness).
Experimenting on injured soldiers during the Crimean War (without their awareness)

questions.content: What is unique about a cannulated or fistulated cow?

choices: They have two stomachs instead of the normal four
They have four stomachs instead of the normal single stomach
They chew their cud as if they are ruminants
Their large intestine is missing
They have a hole in their side in which you can access their stomach

questions.content:
The number of dairy cows in the U.S. has decreased by ______ since 1960, while total milk production has risen _____.
Note: to calculate a percent change, use the following formula: % change in X = (new value of X – old value of X)/(old value of X). If this percent change is -10%, that means it has decreased 10%.
In 1960 the average cow produced 755 gallons per year, while the average cow today produces ________ gallons per year.
To produce a gallon of milk today, dairy cows today need only _____ of the feed and ______ of the water they would have needed in 1945.
The carbon footprint of a gallon of milk in 1945 was about ________ times higher than the footprint today.
Although more milk is produced in the U.S. today than in 1945, the total carbon footprint from all milk production is _______ of that in 1945.

Suppose that, over time, the carbon footprint from one gallon of milk is cut in half, but over that time period total milk production rose 70%. How would the total carbon emissions from all milk production change?

choices: It would remain the same

questions.content: Suppose that, over time, the carbon footprint from one gallon of milk is cut in half, but over that time period total milk production rose 100%. How would the total carbon emissions from all milk production change?
Cows emit methane as they ______, and they do so about ______ every minute.
The black and white cows you see in Chick-fil-A commercials are called ____________ cows and are the most popular breed due to their superior milk production.
Small, brown dairy cows are called ____________ cows, and have the advantage of converting feed to milk more efficiently and producing more ___________ in their milk.
The popular dairy breeds in the U.S. all originated from

choices: South America (including the Falkland Islands)

questions.content: A farmer in the Elizabethan Age would predict a cow’s milk production by

choices: Whether it was a full moon when the cow was born
The number of baptisms taking place in the local community when the cow was born
Whether the cow had straight or curved horns
The direction of its hairs on the rear part of her udder

questions.content: The twentieth century saw great improvements in nutrition science, such as cracking grain to make them more easily digestible by cattle. Another improvement is providing feed based on the cows’ _______ needs, not her _______ needs.
A dairy cow’s diet is determined by the cow’s nutritional needs, the price of various feeds, and _______.

choices: Rules-of-thumb about how the feed should be designed
Recommendations based on the farmers’ almanac

question_set.title: Quiz: The Carbon Footprint of Milk

tag:nextthought.com,2011-10:OKState-NAQ-.title: Quiz: The Carbon Footprint of Milk

questions.content: What happens to dairy cows when they are no longer used for milking?

choices: Allowed to live in pastures until they die.
Slaughtered and made into dog food only.
Slaughtered and carcass is buried, not used for anything.

questions.content: Females calves are usually kept by the farmer for milking, but according to Bailey’s sources, _____ of male calves are raised for beef and _______ are raised for veal.
Dairy cows are milked ______ times each day and, once hooked up to a milking machine, a single milking takes ______________.

choices: 2-3 times; ten minutes

questions.content: When is the calf taken away from its mother?

choices: Immediately after it is born
Soon after birth, once the mother has cleaned the calf
When it is one month old
When it is nine weeks old

questions.content: Why are calves kept in individual pens until they are weaned?

choices: To prevent the spread of disease
To help monitor the calves’ health
To prevent calves from attempting to nurse one another
a, b, and c

questions.content: Colostrum is a substance present in a mammal’s milk for a short period after giving birth, and is high in antibodies to give her baby’s immune system a boost. How do dairy farmers ensure that calves receive high quality colostrum?

choices: By feeding it a synthetic colostrum, made in a factory, but scientifically tested to make sure it resembles the milk produced by dairy cows
By only breeding cows known to have high quality colostrum
By testing the mother’s colostrum before her baby can drink it
By giving the calf colostrum from a cow other than its mother, a cow whose colostrum has been tested for antibodies

questions.content: Match the age of the calf with the change in how it is fed:

values: fed formula milk twice a day
fed formula milk only once a day
grain and forage added to diet of formula milk
weaned completely

questions.content: What is forage?
Why don’t the black and white cows seen in Chick-fil-a commercials have horns?

choices: They are a breed of cows who do not grow horns
They are a breed of cows whose horns fall off at about one year of age
The horns are removed by the farmer
In the commercials, the horns were taken out of the picture at video editing

questions.content: At the OSU farm, and many farms like it, to what extent are cattle given antibiotics?

choices: Calves used to receive antibiotics shortly after weaning, but that practice is declining
Cows are given antibiotics while they are producing milk, in order to increase milk production
Whenever dairy cattle are sick with a bacterial infection

questions.content: What do we call a female calf before she gives birth for the first time?
At what age are female dairy cattle provided shelter with comfortable bedding?

choices: After weaning but before giving birth
Cow stage, after she has given birth and is providing milk
Cow stage, between giving birth, while they are pregnant but not being milked
All of the above

questions.content: How are most dairy cattle bred?

choices: Natural mating with live bulls

questions.content: While cows are being artificially inseminated, one arm holds the metal rod with the thawed semen, while the other hand

choices: Massages the cow’s hindquarters to keep her calm
Is up the cow’s rectum, grasping and manipulating the cervix
Is in the cow’s vagina, widening with cervix with the person’s fingers
Holds the tail to keep it from swatting the person
Massages the back of the cow’s udder to keep her calm

questions.content: Heifers will usually conceive at _______ months and give birth for the first time at _______ months of age.
Cows might find being milked a pleasant experience because it

choices: provides variability in their daily activities
relieves pressure in their udders

questions.content: Match the following activities in the milking parlor with the order in which they are performed. Answer with “1” for the first activity, “2” for the second activity, and so on.

values: Dip udder teats in iodine
Dip udder teats in hydrogen peroxide
Manually milk cow to check milk for signs of mastitis

questions.content: Cows being milked may choose to eat little grass, even if plenty is available. Why?

choices: Stress from separation from her calf
The ample availability of other foods she likes better
The pastures are too crowded with other cows
The presence of cow manure on the pasture gives the grass a bad taste
She is too tired from being milked

questions.content: In the video, what type of bedding is used in the shelters for the cows being milked?
The “dry lot” refers to a pasture with shelter where the cow is kept

choices: After being washed by hand
After she is too old to conceive and produce milk
Not to be milked, but to let her rest before giving birth again
When they are weaned but not old enough to mingle in herds with adult cows

questions.content: Roughly speaking, a productive cow will give birth how many times before she is culled?

choices: Three or perhaps four or five

tag:nextthought.com,2011-10:OKState-NAQ-.title: Quiz: Virtual Tour of OSU Dairy Farm

questions.content: Suppose that African Americans are 10% of the American public. A sample of individuals asked to complete a survey (which will be used to describe the food preferences of all Americans) is representative if the percent of African Americans in the sample is …

choices: Any percentage greater than 10%

questions.content: The Nielson ratings, used to measure the popularity of TV shows, operate by documenting which shows families with the last name of “Nielson” watch.
A representative sample includes only those individuals who make up the majority of a population.

Suppose you are conducting a survey of Americans about what practices they feel are most important for ensuring beef is safe to eat at restaurants. Specifically, you ask the following question of everyone.
In your opinion, which of he following practices are most important for ensuring the safety of beef. Rank them in order of importance, with 1 = most important and 5 = least important.
______Proper cooking of beef by restaurant
______Tracking the animal throughout the food system, from the farms on which it was reared, to the facility it was slaughtered, to the restaurant it was served
______Strict food safety laws in the slaughtering of cattle and processing of beef
______Limited use of antibiotics on the farm
______Raising the cattle in natural environment, and feeding them natural feed
You are concerned the rankings will be impacted by the order in which the items are listed. For instance, you are concerned that “proper cooking of beef” will be given a ranking of “1” most frequently simply because it is the first item on the list. What can be done to prevent this bias?

choices: Place the item with the most words as the first option, so that individuals will not be discouraged from reading the other answers
Ask the respondents not to allow the ordering of the items to influence their responses
Randomize the ordering of the items across surveys
Make the items appearing last in the list a bigger font
There is nothing you can do to prevent this bias

questions.content: In Dr. Norwood’s survey, those who went on a low-carb diet increased their consumption of beef and pork, but decreased their consumption of chicken/turkey.
In Dr. Norwood’s survey, of those who went on a low-carb diet, more of them increased their consumption of yogurt than those who decreased their consumption.

Those who use low-carb diets often consume more of other foods to replace some of the loss in calories from carbs. In Dr. Norwood’s survey, of those who use low-carb diets, which food item is most commonly increased item on a low-carb diet?
When on a low-carb diet, many individuals increase their consumption of Greek yogurt.

When asked in surveys, ______ of Americans believe that low meat prices are more important than the well-being of farm animals; _____ of respondents also indicated that the average American believes that low meat prices are more important than the well-being of farm animals.
In surveys, a majority of Americans indicate that they are very concerned about the well-being of farm animals, but they believe the average American is not.
The Lake Wobegon Effect describes a situation where most people believe they are below average in something.
If 55% of Americans in a survey indicate they will pay 10% higher egg prices if layers are treated better, the actual percent of Americans is more than 55%.

Dr. Norwood’s research suggests that, to determine the extent to which people care about the well-being of farm animals, instead of asking respondents what they think, one should instead ask what they believe the average American thinks.
If an economist says a steak is worth $20 to a specific person, what does that mean?

choices: The person believes that society places twice as much worth to that steak than a steak priced $10.
The person believes that the average person will pay up to $20, but no more than $20, for the steak.
The person believes other people deserve this steak twice as much as a $10 steak.
The person will himself/herself will buy the steak whenever it is priced less than $20.

questions.content: Economists define the “value” of a good to a person as the person’s maximum willingness-to-pay for the good.
How does one go about obtaining a representative sample?

choices: Randomly select people from the population of individuals you are studying.
Select one attribute of the population of interest, and make sure all of your sample matches that one attribute.
Select one attribute of the population of interest, and make sure all of your sample approximately matches that one attribute.

questions.content: A consumer survey or experiment is only scientifically valid if the percent of females in the sample and the population match exactly.
A self-selection bias occurs when people who volunteer to participate in a consumer survey or experiment are different in some way from those who do not participate.
One way of mitigating the self-selection bias is by paying people rather large amounts of money to volunteer for a consumer survey or experiment.

The art of “controlling as much as you can” means that, if you are trying to determine the degree to which a person likes the taste of skim milk versus regular milk, you should have the person taste both milks while the person is fully aware of which milk is which.

Randomizing what you cannot control means that, if you are measuring the value consumers place on milk produced with and without rBST, and you are having them taste each milk type before assigning them a value, roughly half of the subjects should taste the milk made with rBST first, while the other half tastes the other milk first.

tag:nextthought.com,2011-10:OKState-NAQ-.content: Suppose that African Americans are 10% of the American public. A sample of individuals asked to complete a survey (which will be used to describe the food preferences of all Americans) is representative if the percent of African Americans in the sample is …

choices: Any percentage greater than 10%

tag:nextthought.com,2011-10:OKState-NAQ-.content: The Nielson ratings, used to measure the popularity of TV shows, operate by documenting which shows families with the last name of “Nielson” watch.
A representative sample includes only those individuals who make up the majority of a population.

Suppose you are conducting a survey of Americans about what practices they feel are most important for ensuring beef is safe to eat at restaurants. Specifically, you ask the following question of everyone.
In your opinion, which of he following practices are most important for ensuring the safety of beef. Rank them in order of importance, with 1 = most important and 5 = least important.
______Proper cooking of beef by restaurant
______Tracking the animal throughout the food system, from the farms on which it was reared, to the facility it was slaughtered, to the restaurant it was served
______Strict food safety laws in the slaughtering of cattle and processing of beef
______Limited use of antibiotics on the farm
______Raising the cattle in natural environment, and feeding them natural feed
You are concerned the rankings will be impacted by the order in which the items are listed. For instance, you are concerned that “proper cooking of beef” will be given a ranking of “1” most frequently simply because it is the first item on the list. What can be done to prevent this bias?

choices: Place the item with the most words as the first option, so that individuals will not be discouraged from reading the other answers
Ask the respondents not to allow the ordering of the items to influence their responses
Randomize the ordering of the items across surveys
Make the items appearing last in the list a bigger font
There is nothing you can do to prevent this bias

tag:nextthought.com,2011-10:OKState-NAQ-.content: In Dr. Norwood’s survey, those who went on a low-carb diet increased their consumption of beef and pork, but decreased their consumption of chicken/turkey.
In Dr. Norwood’s survey, of those who went on a low-carb diet, more of them increased their consumption of yogurt than those who decreased their consumption.

Those who use low-carb diets often consume more of other foods to replace some of the loss in calories from carbs. In Dr. Norwood’s survey, of those who use low-carb diets, which food item is most commonly increased item on a low-carb diet?
When on a low-carb diet, many individuals increase their consumption of Greek yogurt.

When asked in surveys, ______ of Americans believe that low meat prices are more important than the well-being of farm animals; _____ of respondents also indicated that the average American believes that low meat prices are more important than the well-being of farm animals.
In surveys, a majority of Americans indicate that they are very concerned about the well-being of farm animals, but they believe the average American is not.
The Lake Wobegon Effect describes a situation where most people believe they are below average in something.
If 55% of Americans in a survey indicate they will pay 10% higher egg prices if layers are treated better, the actual percent of Americans is more than 55%.

Dr. Norwood’s research suggests that, to determine the extent to which people care about the well-being of farm animals, instead of asking respondents what they think, one should instead ask what they believe the average American thinks.
If an economist says a steak is worth $20 to a specific person, what does that mean?

choices: The person believes that society places twice as much worth to that steak than a steak priced $10.
The person believes that the average person will pay up to $20, but no more than $20, for the steak.
The person believes other people deserve this steak twice as much as a $10 steak.
The person will himself/herself will buy the steak whenever it is priced less than $20.

tag:nextthought.com,2011-10:OKState-NAQ-.content: Economists define the “value” of a good to a person as the person’s maximum willingness-to-pay for the good.
How does one go about obtaining a representative sample?

choices: Randomly select people from the population of individuals you are studying.
Select one attribute of the population of interest, and make sure all of your sample matches that one attribute.
Select one attribute of the population of interest, and make sure all of your sample approximately matches that one attribute.

tag:nextthought.com,2011-10:OKState-NAQ-.content: A consumer survey or experiment is only scientifically valid if the percent of females in the sample and the population match exactly.
A self-selection bias occurs when people who volunteer to participate in a consumer survey or experiment are different in some way from those who do not participate.
One way of mitigating the self-selection bias is by paying people rather large amounts of money to volunteer for a consumer survey or experiment.

The art of “controlling as much as you can” means that, if you are trying to determine the degree to which a person likes the taste of skim milk versus regular milk, you should have the person taste both milks while the person is fully aware of which milk is which.

Randomizing what you cannot control means that, if you are measuring the value consumers place on milk produced with and without rBST, and you are having them taste each milk type before assigning them a value, roughly half of the subjects should taste the milk made with rBST first, while the other half tastes the other milk first.

choices: Any percentage greater than 10%

German author Johann Wolfgang von Goethe used an unusual method for negotiating the royalties with his publisher. Under this method, if Goethe demanded 18% royalties and his publisher offered 20%, the publisher can then publish his work.
If Goethe demanded 18% royalties and his publisher offered 15%, the publisher can then publish his work and Goethe will receive 15% royalties.
If Goethe demanded 8% royalties and his publisher offered 15%, the publisher can then publish his work and Goethe will receive 15% royalties.
If Goethe demanded 8% royalties and his publisher offered 15%, the publisher can then publish his work and Goethe will receive 8% royalties.
What was Goethe’s primary motivation for this strange negotiating arrangement?

choices: To determine exactly how much his writings were valued to publishers.
To negotiate higher royalties that publisher who submitted the offer.
To confuse the publisher, allowing Goethe to gain negotiating power.
To get out of a contract with his publisher.

questions.content: Agricultural economists dislike using auctions in experiments because it invokes a sense of competitive behavior that is absent in the grocery store.
People will reveal their true value for a good when they know they will pay a price less than that true value.
Another name for the second-price auction is the English auction.
Another name for the second-price auction is the Vickrey auction.
In a second-price auction, suppose that 5 individuals submit bids of: bidder 1 = $10, bidder 2 = $12, bidder 3 = $15, bidder 4 = $20, bidder 5 = $22. Who wins the auction and receives the good?
In a second-price auction, suppose that 5 individuals submit bids of: bidder 1 = $10, bidder 2 = $12, bidder 3 = $15, bidder 4 = $20, bidder 5 = $22. What is the price paid by the auction winner?

choices: There is no auction winner.

questions.content: What is the reason for using a second-price auction?

choices: To sell the good for a higher price than could be obtained in a Vickrey auction
To determine if the Vickrey auction is biased
To determine consumers’ maximum willingness-to-pay for the good
To determine consumers’ true value for the good

questions.content: In the Kant, Messer, and Kaiser (KMK) study, the sample was imperfect due to (Select all that apply.)

choices: The sample was drawn from the same, small region
The small amount of money offered is unlikely to attract more wealthy people
They only studied college students
They only attracted students who would participate for free

questions.content: In the Kant, Messer, and Kaiser (KMK) study, they were able to control the setting by (Select all that apply.)

choices: Giving identical written and oral information to all participants
Encouraging participants to discuss their preferences for the milk they tasted with each other
Each milk was served in a glass that also contained the seller’s brand and logo

questions.content: In the Kant, Messer, and Kaiser (KMK) study, they randomized things they could not control by (Select all that apply.)

choices: Randomly assigning participants a computer
Making sure the most expensive milk was tasted first
Having the subjects taste the milk blindfolded
Asking the subject to attend a research session at a randomly determined time of the day

questions.content: Suppose that one is studying preferences for low-fat milk. In an experiment, on average, males value low-fat milk at $4.50 per gallon while the average for females is $5.25. In the experiment, males were 75% of the sample while females were 25%. What is the average value of low-fat milk in the sample?

Suppose that one is studying preferences for low-fat milk. In an experiment, on average, males value low-fat milk at $4.50 per gallon while the average for females is $5.25. In the experiment, males were 75% of the sample while females were 25%. The researcher is interested in studying the value of milk to those in the household who do the shopping. Research reveals that grocery store shoppers are 75% female and 25% male. What is the predicted value of low-fat milk to the population of grocery store shoppers?

The KMK study calculated the value of organic, rBST, and non-rBST milk (“rBST milk” refers to milk from cows that were administered rBST injections). What was the relative value of each milk type, according to Result #1? Answer by placing the highest valued milk on top and the lowest value milk on bottom.

parts.input:
1.
2.
3.

questions.content: The KMK study determined that, when consumers are first presented with non-rBST milk, the value of rBST milk is lower than it would be if the consumer was presented first with rBST milk.
According to KMK Result #2, the presence of non-rBST milk does not stigmatize rBST milk.

Upload your milk label image.

tag:nextthought.com,2011-10:OKState-NAQ-.content: Upload your milk label image.

questions.content: Upload your milk label image.
Upload your milk label image.

tag:nextthought.com,2011-10:OKState-NAQ-.content: Upload your milk label image.

questions.content: Upload your milk label image.
Many milk cartons contain the remark, “Our farmers pledge not to use artificial growth hormones.” Such cartons will also contain the remark, …

choices: The FDA states that failure to abide by this pledge can result in fine and imprisonment.
The FDA states that artificial growth hormones pose no hazard to cattle health
The FDA states there is no difference in the quality or safety of milk with or without the use of rBST.
The FDA states that such pledges are only binding for cattle milked in the U.S.

questions.content: The acronym “BST” stands for
What is BST?

choices: A sedative causing the cows to move less and thus eat less feed
A probiotic that enhances the gut bacteria that helps produce milk
A hormone that directs the cow’s body to produce more milk
An antibiotic that reduces bacteria concentrations in cow milk
An antibiotic that enhances milk production through means not yet understood

questions.content: Today, cows can be injected with rBST, thereby increasing milk production. Why is rBST more affordable than BST?

choices: Because the rBST is manufactured using a genetically modified bacterium
Because it can be acquired from the pituitary glands of slaughtered cattle, which are in ample supply
Because it can be manufactured from genetically modified cattle, and transferred to regular cattle
Because rBST can be legally produced in countries with low animal welfare standards
Because rBST is manufactured in the presence of antibiotics

questions.content: rBST is administered to cattle by adding it to cattle feed.
Farmers who administer rBST to their dairy cattle find it increases milk production by ________. Nevertheless, less than _________ of cattle in the U.S. receive rBST.
Consumers will pay more for milk containing the pledge in the aforementioned question, but the qualifying statement regarding the FDAs position is printed along with the pledge to …

choices: Prevent the milk seller from being sued for false advertisements
Help provide consumers all the information they need to make wise choices
To warn consumers that domestic and internationally produced milk are produced under different standards.
To assure the consumer that the pledge is enforced by the government.

questions.content: When economists think about milk sold with a label saying the farmers did not administer rBST to their cattle, economists conclude … Select all that apply.

choices: The pledge gives misleading information, suggesting milk produced using rBST is not safe, when in fact it is.
If consumers are concerned about the use of rBST—regardless of whether they should be concerned—they might have the right to know whether it was used in milk production.
rBST should not be used because it both increases the cost of milk production and frightens consumers
rBST cannot possibly comply with food safety regulations, and thus should not be used.

questions.content: Science allows us to achieve great feats, but intuition about what is a “natural” reminds us that you cannot predict all the consequences of a new technology.
Scientists had once approved the feeding of rendered sheep carcasses to cattle, but such practices may have caused Mad Cow disease.
Some farmers feed processed chicken manure to cattle.
The Food and Drug Administration and virtually every prestigious scientific institution agrees that milk produced using rBST is safe.
Giving cows injections of rBST decreases the rate of mastitis infections in dairy cows.
The FDA has a zero tolerance for antibiotic residues in milk, but between 5 and 10% of milk samples test positive for residues.
The FDA has recently become concerned with higher IGF-1 levels in milk from cows treated with rBST, and might consider banning rBST as a result.
An Ohio court ruled that milk produced with and without rBST are essentially identical.
Because the FDA approves of rBST in milk production, over 75% of dairy cows in the U.S. receive rBST.

question_set.title: Quiz: rBST Growth Hormone in Milk Production

tag:nextthought.com,2011-10:OKState-NAQ-.title: Quiz: rBST Growth Hormone in Milk Production

Giving cows injections of rBST decreases the rate of mastitis infections in dairy cows.
The FDA has a zero tolerance for antibiotic residues in milk, but between 5 and 10% of milk samples test positive for residues.
The FDA has recently become concerned with higher IGF-1 levels in milk from cows treated with rBST, and might consider banning rBST as a result.
An Ohio court ruled that milk produced with and without rBST are essentially identical.
Because the FDA approves of rBST in milk production, over 75% of dairy cows in the U.S. receive rBST.

questions.content: Many milk cartons contain the remark, “Our farmers pledge not to use artificial growth hormones.” Such cartons will also contain the remark, …

choices: The FDA states that failure to abide by this pledge can result in fine and imprisonment.
The FDA states that artificial growth hormones pose no hazard to cattle health
The FDA states there is no difference in the quality or safety of milk with or without the use of rBST.
The FDA states that such pledges are only binding for cattle milked in the U.S.

questions.content: The acronym “BST” stands for
What is BST?

choices: A sedative causing the cows to move less and thus eat less feed
A probiotic that enhances the gut bacteria that helps produce milk
A hormone that directs the cow’s body to produce more milk
An antibiotic that reduces bacteria concentrations in cow milk
An antibiotic that enhances milk production through means not yet understood

questions.content: Today, cows can be injected with rBST, thereby increasing milk production. Why is rBST more affordable than BST?

choices: Because the rBST is manufactured using a genetically modified bacterium
Because it can be acquired from the pituitary glands of slaughtered cattle, which are in ample supply
Because it can be manufactured from genetically modified cattle, and transferred to regular cattle
Because rBST can be legally produced in countries with low animal welfare standards
Because rBST is manufactured in the presence of antibiotics

questions.content: rBST is administered to cattle by adding it to cattle feed.
Farmers who administer rBST to their dairy cattle find it increases milk production by ________. Nevertheless, less than _________ of cattle in the U.S. receive rBST.
Consumers will pay more for milk containing the pledge in the aforementioned question, but the qualifying statement regarding the FDAs position is printed along with the pledge to …

choices: Prevent the milk seller from being sued for false advertisements
Help provide consumers all the information they need to make wise choices
To warn consumers that domestic and internationally produced milk are produced under different standards.
To assure the consumer that the pledge is enforced by the government.

questions.content: When economists think about milk sold with a label saying the farmers did not administer rBST to their cattle, economists conclude … Select all that apply.

choices: The pledge gives misleading information, suggesting milk produced using rBST is not safe, when in fact it is.
If consumers are concerned about the use of rBST—regardless of whether they should be concerned—they might have the right to know whether it was used in milk production.
rBST should not be used because it both increases the cost of milk production and frightens consumers
rBST cannot possibly comply with food safety regulations, and thus should not be used.

questions.content: Science allows us to achieve great feats, but intuition about what is a “natural” reminds us that you cannot predict all the consequences of a new technology.
Scientists had once approved the feeding of rendered sheep carcasses to cattle, but such practices may have caused Mad Cow disease.
Some farmers feed processed chicken manure to cattle.
The Food and Drug Administration and virtually every prestigious scientific institution agrees that milk produced using rBST is safe.
Giving cows injections of rBST decreases the rate of mastitis infections in dairy cows.
The FDA has a zero tolerance for antibiotic residues in milk, but between 5 and 10% of milk samples test positive for residues.
The FDA has recently become concerned with higher IGF-1 levels in milk from cows treated with rBST, and might consider banning rBST as a result.
An Ohio court ruled that milk produced with and without rBST are essentially identical.
Because the FDA approves of rBST in milk production, over 75% of dairy cows in the U.S. receive rBST.

tag:nextthought.com,2011-10:OKState-NAQ-.title: Quiz: rBST Growth Hormone in Milk Production

questions.content: What are some reasons agriculture relies upon an understanding of DNA? Select all reasons discussed in the introductory video. (Select all that apply.)

choices: To develop improved varieties of rice
To breed hornless Holstein cows
To prevent birth defects in Red Angus bulls
To breed Holsteins that can reproduce asexually
To better understand the ways in which viruses and bacteria can infect both cattle and humans

questions.content: Although the DNA of different organisms look similar, they are made of different types of molecules.
Much of the information inherent in DNA is found in the sequence in which the phosphate and Deoxribose molecules appear.
The information inherent in DNA is found in the sequence in which the nucleotides appear.
Which of the following are nucleotides found in DNA? (Select all that apply.)
The Thymine nucleotide is always matched with the Adenine nucleotide in DNA.
The Guanine nucleotide is always matched with the Lytosine nucleotide in DNA.
The DNA of an organism can be represented by a long sequence of three to five nucleotides.
Once you know the sequence of nucleotides on one side of a DNA, you can infer the sequence of nucleotides on the other side.
Suppose you have a sequence of the following nucleotides on a portion of the DNA: Guanine, Guanine, Adenine, Guanine, Adenine. How is this sequence represented by scientists?
Using the colors matched with each nucleotide in the video, what would be the sequence of letters describing the DNA strand below?
Using the colors matched with each nucleotide in the video, what would be the sequence of letters describing the opposite side of DNA strand below?
How many letters comprise (one side) of the S. aureus DNA?
If you printed a hard copy of the S. aureus DNA using 12-point font, on paper 2.5 feet wide, what would be the length of the paper?
How many letters comprise (one side) of human DNA?
The enormous diversity of life on earth is not due to the size of organisms’ DNA, but the large number of different nucleotides the DNA is made of.
To determine if the same S. aureus that infected humans also infected cattle, scientists had to determine if the entire genome of some of the bacteria found in humans and cow milk were identical.
What is the sequence of letters below?

choices: A sequence of DNA unique in the genome of S. aureus
A sequence of DNA unique in both S. aureus and humans
The portion of the S. aureus DNA that determines whether it will thrive in cow milk
A sequence of DNA from the human genome after it has been infected by S. aureus
This cannot be the DNA of an organism

question_set.title: Quiz: The Health of Dairy Cows and Humans
